description: The project was to build a south facing, upside-down, partially underground, passive, airtight, low-energy, infill-urban brutalist home, that would allow our family to stay within our local community.

events.name: Drop in
events.notes: We'll be walking you though the house in groups of  5 - 10

factsheet.heading: Fact Sheet:
paragraphs: The Key Principles of the build:

Building Down / upside down: We couldn’t build up because of the surrounding cardens, and there are usually at least 6 of us, so we had to dig, but we kept the bedrooms on the lower floor so that the ‘public’spaces would have a better connection to the garden. This meant a lot of underpinning/foundations.

Brutalist ‘honest’ construction: we feel that a building should express what it is made of, so all of that mass of material used to underpin and retain the surrounding ground needed to be expressed internally.
High thermal Mass: having all of the mass of concrete expressed internally resulted a huge amount of thermal mass which informed the environmental strategy, one of thermal inertia.
Passive Solar Gain: the house is arranged around one large internal south facing living space.  The tree provides critical shading in summer.
Garden Spaces: we’ve created a series of sunken gardens carved out of the ground to ensure good natural light to all of the lower living spaces.
